body: @Victoronz @re0312 one of you may be interested in investigating this.
What does the performance of the `unsafe` equivalent using `Query::get_unchecked` look like?

Hi @alice-i-cecile,

I'm not sure how I'd use `Query::get_unchecked` in this situation but I've tried `Query::iter_combinations_unsafe` and that seems to have the same performance.

I hope that helps, but if you want me to try `Query::get_unchecked` then could you let me know how to modify the algorithm in question?

issue.title: inline iter_combinations

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective
- fix #14679 
-  bevy's performance highly depends on compiler optimization,inline hot function could greatly help compiler to optimize our program

body:
Can you try #14680 to see if it solves your problem?
On my machine, the cost of 1000 entities reduced from approximately 4ms to 1ms

Thanks @re0312, this does actually seem quite a bit faster. Still not quite as fast as the Nannou version, but better! Sorry, I don't have actual performance figures to back up these claims, but visually it is definitely "faster".

> Thanks @re0312, this does actually seem quite a bit faster. Still not quite as fast as the Nannou version, but better! Sorry, I don't have actual performance figures to back up these claims, but visually it is definitely "faster".

yeah,I tested Bevy and Nannou, even with 14680 Bevy is still about 2x slower than Nannou. our current iter_combinations still has a lot of room for optimization

> yeah,I tested Bevy and Nannou, even with 14680 Bevy is still about 2x slower than Nannou. our current iter_combinations still has a lot of room for optimization

Thanks for investigating and testing it for me :+1:
